newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: South Africa said to seek arms deal with Beijing.
newsitem.headline: South Africa said to seek arms deal with Beijing.

text.p: South Africa is negotiating to sell advanced military technology to China in a deal worth about one billion rand, or $220 million, the Sunday newspaper Rapport said on Sunday.
The Afrikaans-language weekly said Brian Blackbeard of the arms manufacturer Reutech -- part of the state-run Armscor conglomerate -- had confirmed that a contract was being sought with Beijing.

No independent confirmation was immediately available. However, the report fits recent assertions by President Nelson Mandela's government that South Africa has a world-class arms industry and intends to export wherever it chooses.
Rapport said China was interested in a variety of high-tech arms and equipment, including two dimensional radar, with the possibility of a later upgrade to three-dimensional scanning.
The paper quoted Blackbeard as saying the South African system was extremely sophisticated and ranked as "the best in the world".
China was specifically interested in the radar system because it fitted its military requirements, it quoted Blackbeard as saying.
The arms deal would also include a tank firing and guidance system like the one South Africa may yet sell to Syria, if it is prepared to defy strong United States objections.
Rapport said however that while Syria could be offered a straight sale of equipment to upgrade its tanks, South Africa could make a deal allowing China to manufacture and develop the system.
A leak of cabinet documents last month disclosed that South Africa was preparing to tender for a major contract to upgrade Syrian's ageing, Soviet-built T-72 tanks.

The United States, which regards Syria as a terrorist state, warned it would cut off aid to South Africa if such a deal went ahead, prompting an angry Mandela to tell Washington his government would do business with whomever it chose, whether or not they were friends of the West.
South Africa has made no final decision on whether to pursue the Syrian contract.
